Border patrol told me heartbreaking stories about migrants losing their lives and how their law enforcement work becomes difficult search and rescue missions. They described dangers of floods and toxic waste in the Tijuana River Channel that endanger migrants and agents. (14/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_LVjg9UYAEJJwE.jpg

By eliminating any way to even apply for asylum, the U.S. government is enabling human traffickers to control the process or leaving the strong and fit to their own efforts. Left behind are women, children, elderly, and people with disabilities. (13/x)

She had family to welcome her to the U.S. as did all the other migrants that I spoke with. One woman came to TX from Ecuador. She was held in detention for days, flown overnight to CA for ‚Äúprocessing,‚Äù then deposited at the shelter. I visited Embajadores de Jes√∫s in Tijuana, run by a compassionate pastor who tries to shelter everyone. I saw hundreds of people who have no home and no next step, peacefully and patiently sharing one room. No privacy. No personal belongings. (9/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_LVD31VQAk3GIY.jpg

I visited Tijuana and saw the circumstances facing migrants. In the Chaparral camp, gangs control migrants‚Äô lives, often extorting or victimizing them. The violence makes it unsafe for advocates to visit, and I viewed at a distance. (8/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_LU5-5VIAEMKdI.jpg

The response was silence. Here is the truth: There is no process. A person fleeing violence cannot go to our border and apply for asylum. If you walk up to the border without a visa or U.S. residence, you are ignored. How can migrants get in line if there is no line? (7/x)

A common point raised about our immigration policy is that those seeking to build a life in the U.S. should ‚Äúwait in line.‚Äù So I asked U.S. Customs and Border Patrol to show me the line. Where would a refugee go? How does screening occur? How long is the wait? (6/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_LUyBFVgAM63JY.jpg

However, secure borders are not sealed borders. A regular and orderly process for entry‚Äîfor everything from goods to asylees‚Äîis required by U.S. and international laws. One-third of the people I represent are foreign born, and they are neighbors and co-workers. (5/x)

Border patrol told me that our border is the most secure in its history. Federal data show that the top country of origin for new immigrants is China. Visa overstays now outnumber unlawful border crossings as the main source of unauthorized immigration to the U.S. (4/x)

At the busiest port of entry, San Ysidro, I saw new screening technology, including biometric and vehicle scanning tools. I crossed into the U.S., seeing for myself how agents use technology, experience, and training to identify unlawful activity. (I was admitted!) (3/x) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E_LUFdPUUAQHQn5.jpg

Borders are a necessary part of defining a nation-state. Each country sets border policy on the people and goods that enter and exit, and does so in the context of its neighbors, global affairs, and values. That policy should be lawful and fair. (2/x)

I visited the U.S.-Mexico border to listen and to learn. Partisan pundits are no substitute for seeing for yourself. (Disclaimer: the border is not a monolith.
